references.O97SEN01USGP: Senner, Stanley E. and Brian J. Mccaffery. 1997. Surfbird (Aphriza virgata), The Birds of North America Online (A. Poole, Ed.). Ithaca: Cornell Lab of Ornithology; Retrieved from the Birds of North America Online: http://bna.birds.cornell.edu/bna/species/266
references.N77CON01USGP: Connors, C. S. 1977. Foraging ecology of Black Turnstones and Surfbirds on their wintering grounds at Bodega Bay, California. Master's Thesis. Univ. of California, Berkeley.
references.A86MAR01USGP: Marsh, C.P. 1986. Rocky intertidal community organization: the impact of avian predators on mussel recruitment. Ecology, 67(3):771-786.
references.B90ZEI03NAUS: Zeiner, D. C., W. F. Laudenslayer Jr., and K. E. Mayer (editors). 1990. California's Wildlife. Vol. 2. Birds. California Statewide Wildlife Habitat Relat. System, California. Resources Agency, Dept. Fish and Game, Sacramento, California.
references.A44GRI01USGP: Grinnell, J. and A. H. Miller. 1944. The distribution of the birds of California. Pac. Coast Avifauna no. 27. Cooper Ornithol. Club, Berkeley, CA.

habitat_description: Aphriza virgata winters along the Pacific coast, inhabiting rocky shores, ledges, and reefs. It is sometimes found on tidal mudflats and on sandy beaches near rocky areas (Grinnell and Miller, 1944; Connors, 1977; Marsh, 1986; Senner and McCaffery, 1997).
